TEI:
Kalittokai 65.
iḵtu iravukkuṟi alarā meṉṟañcit talaivaṉai nīkki niṟuttak karutiya tōḻi “allakuṟip paṭutalu mavaḷvayi ṉurittē - yavaṉkuṟi mayaṅkiya vamaivoṭu variṉē” (to.po.133) eṉṉuñ cūttirattāṉ allakuṟippaṭutal taṉakkum urittākaliṉ, avaṉ ceyta kuṟiyaṟi-taṟkup puṟattuc ceṉṟavaḻi, āṇṭup piṟantatōr ceytiyāka oru poyyai nāṭakavaḻakkum ulakiyalvaḻakkumākap puṉainturai-vakaiyāṟ paṭaittukkoṇṭu, piṟṟai ñāṉṟu talaivaṉ ciṟaip-puṟamākat talaivikkuk kūṟiyatu. itaṉai “irantu kuṟaiyuṟṟa kiḻavaṉait tōḻi - nirampa nīkki niṟuttalaṉṟiyum - vāymai kūṟalum poytalaip peytalum – nalvakai yuṭaiya nalattiṟ kūṟiyum – palvakai yāṉum paṭaikkavum peṟumē” (to.po.134) eṉa vaḻuvamaittavāṟṟāṟ koḷka.
tiruntiḻāy kēḷāynam mūrkkellāñ cālum
perunakai yalka ṉikaḻnta torunilaiyē
maṉpatai yellā maṭinta viruṅkaṅku
lantukiṟ pōrvai yaṇipeṟat taiinam
miṉcāyaṉ mārpaṉ kuṟiniṉṟēṉ yāṉākat
tīrat taṟainta talaiyuntaṉ kampaluṅ
kārak kuṟaintu kaṟaippaṭṭu vantunañ
cēriyiṟ pōkā muṭamutir pārppāṉait
tōḻinī pōṟṟuti yeṉṟi yavaṉāṅkē
pārāk kuṟaḻāp paṇiyāp poḻutaṉṟi
yāriva ṇiṉṟī reṉakkūṟip paiyeṉa,
vaikāṇ mutupakaṭṭiṟ pakkattiṟ pōkātu
taiyā ṟampalan tiṉṟiyō veṉṟutaṉ
paikkaḻittuk koṇṭī yeṉattaralum yātoṉṟum
vāyvāḷē ṉiṟpak kaṭitakaṉṟu kaimāṟik
kaippaṭukkap paṭṭāy ciṟuminī maṟṟiyā
ṉēṉaip picācaru ḷeṉṉai nalitari
ṉivvūrp palinī peṟāamaṟ koḷveṉeṉap
palavun tāṅkātu vāypāṭi niṟpa
mutupārppā ṉañciṉa ṉāta laṟintiyā
ṉeñcā torukai maṇaṟkoṇṭu mēṟṟūvak
kaṇṭē kaṭitaraṟṟip pūcaṟoṭaṅ kiṉaṉāṅkē
yoṭuṅkā vayattiṟ koṭuṅkēḻk kaṭuṅka
ṇirumpuli koṇmār niṟutta valaiyuḷō
rētil kuṟunari paṭṭaṟṟāṟ kātalaṉ
kāṭci yaḻuṅka nammūrk kelāa
mākula māki viḷaintatai yeṉṟuntaṉ
vāḻkkai yatuvākak koṇṭa mutupārppāṉ
vīḻkkaip peruṅkaruṅ kūttu.
You with perfect jewels, listen to what happened at one point
at night, a big laughter worthy of all [the people in] our village: (1f.)
in dark night, when all humanity had dozed off,
when I stood at the meeting place [given] by our man with a sweet handsome chest,
having decoratively fixed a cloak of pretty fine cloth, (3-5)
there he [was], (8cd)
the stooped old brahmin who did not go [away] from our quarter, (8)
having come with [his] head completely flattened(?),
and his garment deficient in lye(?) , being stained, (6f.)
– you would say “friend, be on [your] guard against him.” – (9a-c)
He looked out, bend low, humbled himself [and] said gently
“[this] not being the [proper] time, who are you that stands there?”, (10f.)
without going from [my] side, like an old bull who sees straw, (12)
dislodged his bag(?) [with the words] “woman, would you
eat betel?”, [and] as soon as he gave it [with the words] “take!”, as I stood
[there] without uttering anything at all, he departed quickly, switching over to (13-15)
“you have become possessed, little one! But I (16)
[am] another Piśāca. Be gracious. If you afflict me, (17)
you won’t obtain offerings in this village, I will take [them]”, (18)
[and] as he stood, not lasting many [moments, his] mouth singing the truth(?), (19)
I, knowing that the old brahmin was afraid, (20)
not leaving [it] at that, took up sand with one hand [and] showered it upon [him], (21)
[and] he seeing [that] exclaimed sharply [and] started clamouring. Thus (22)
in a net set up to take a big tiger (24)
with fierce eyes of cruel lustre [and] unrestrained strength (23)
a strange little fox was caught. (25a-c)
When [like that] seeing [our] lover was spoiled,
there being an uproar of our whole village
The big black drama [was] the downfall
of the old brahmin, who got what he had ripened,
as that always was his [way of] life. (25d-29)
